Function: This gene is crucial for brain development, impacting speech, language, and social behavior. Mutations in this gene can lead to conditions like autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by affecting brain circuits involved in language learning and social interaction.
Citation: PeÂ¤agarikano, O., & Geschwind, D. H. (2012). What does CNTNAP2 reveal about autism spectrum disorder? Trends in Molecular Medicine, 18(3), 156?163. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molmed.2012.01.003

Function: This gene is important for our brain development and mental health, especially in conditions like autism. Variation in this gene is linked to traits similar to autism, such as trouble with language and social skills. This gene variation might also affect intelligence.
Citation: Shiota, Y., Hirosawa, T., Yoshimura, Y., Tanaka, S., Hasegawa, C., Iwasaki, S., An, K., Soma, D., Sano, M., Yokoyama, S., & Kikuchi, M. (2021). A common variant of CNTNAP2 is associated with sub-threshold autistic traits and intellectual disability. PLOS ONE, 16(12), e0260548. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0260548

Function: This gene is broken down by the body through two pathways: lysosomes and proteasomes. Problems with these pathways are linked to AD. CNTNAP2 is found in cells alongside markers for these pathways, suggesting it plays a role in keeping brain cells healthy.
Citation: Zhang, Q., Sterling, K., & Song, W. (2023). Degradation of CNTNAP2 is mediated by both macroautophagy?lysosome pathway and ubiquitin?proteasome pathway. Alzheimer?s & Dementia, 19(S1). https://doi.org/10.1002/alz.065334

Function: A gene linked to Alzheimer's disease, plays a crucial role in brain health and memory. It's more prone to certain genetic changes that can affect how it works. In people with Alzheimer's, this gene and others like it tend to be less active in parts of the brain that control memory. This reduced activity may contribute to problems with thinking and remembering in Alzheimer's patients.
Citation: Soheili?Nezhad, S., Van Der Linden, R. J., Rikkert, M. G. M. O., Sprooten, E., & Poelmans, G. (2020). Long genes are more frequently affected by somatic mutations and show reduced expression in Alzheimer?s disease: Implications for disease etiology. Alzheimer?s & Dementia, 17(3), 489?499. https://doi.org/10.1002/alz.12211
